definition: The ability of a fabric to withstand rubbing or friction without showing wear.
A class of dyes that work best in acidic conditions, primarily used for protein fibers like wool and silk.
The attraction between a dye molecule and a fiber, determining how well the dye will bond.
A chemical group that enhances or modifies the color of a chromophore in dye molecules.
The process of removing natural color from fibers to achieve whiteness or prepare for dyeing.
A finishing process that passes fabric through heated rollers to improve surface smoothness and luster.
The part of a dye molecule responsible for color by absorbing certain wavelengths of light.
The resistance of a dyed fabric to fading or running when exposed to various conditions.
A unit of measurement for the linear mass density of fibers, equal to the mass in grams per 9000 meters.
The removal of sizing agents that were applied to warp yarns before weaving.
Water-soluble dyes that can be applied directly to cellulose fibers from an aqueous solution.
Water-insoluble dyes used primarily for synthetic fibers like polyester, applied as fine dispersions.
A dyeing method where fabric is immersed in a dye bath and the dye gradually transfers to the fiber.
A natural or synthetic material that is significantly longer than it is wide, used to make yarn and fabric.
The process of making a dye permanently attach to a fiber through chemical or physical bonds.
Grams per Square Meter - a measurement of fabric weight and thickness.
Having an affinity for water; water-loving. Describes fibers that readily absorb moisture.
Repelling water; water-hating. Describes fibers that resist moisture absorption.
A chemical additive that promotes uniform dye distribution and prevents uneven coloring.
A treatment of cotton with concentrated sodium hydroxide to improve luster, strength, and dye affinity.
A substance that combines with a dye to form an insoluble colored compound, improving fastness.
Colorants derived from plants, animals, or minerals, traditionally used before synthetic dyes.
On Weight of Fiber - a method of expressing chemical concentrations as a percentage of fiber weight.
A continuous dyeing process where fabric is impregnated with dye solution using padder rollers.
A measure of acidity or alkalinity, crucial in dyeing processes for proper dye-fiber interaction.
Dyes that form covalent bonds with fiber molecules, providing excellent wash fastness.
The cleaning process that removes natural and added impurities from textile materials.
A process that burns off protruding fiber ends to create a smooth fabric surface.
The affinity of a dye for a particular fiber without the aid of chemical assistance.
The resistance of a fiber to breaking, usually expressed as force per unit of linear density.
A unit of measurement for fiber linear density, equal to the mass in grams per 1000 meters.
The use of heat to permanently set dyes or finishes in synthetic materials.
Insoluble dyes that are reduced to a soluble form for application, then oxidized to fix the color.
The resistance of dyed fabrics to color change when exposed to water or wet conditions.
